normalised: Okay, so last month was… interesting. Let's just say my stomach decided to stage a full-blown rebellion. It all started subtly, you know? A little bloating after meals, a mild discomfort here and there. I thought it was just the chaat I had from that street vendor near my office in Gurgaon; probably a bit too much spice. Ignored it for a while, popping a Gelusil here and there. Bad move.

normalised: Things escalated pretty quickly. Suddenly, I was experiencing this gnawing pain, especially on an empty stomach. Remember that scene in 'three Idiots' where Raju Rastogi pretends to be sick with all sorts of ailments? It felt like all of those combined, but ten times worse. I tried everything: home remedies, that ajwain concoction my grandmother swears by, even avoiding my beloved rajma chawal for a whole week. Nothing worked.

Found Doctor Sharma online, rated pretty highly, said he specialised in, well, everything gut-related. His clinic was located in Fortis Hospital, Vasant Kunj. Found Dr. Sharma online, rated pretty highly, said he specialised in, well, everything gut-related. His clinic was located in Fortis Hospital, Vasant Kunj. The appointment was for 11:00 AM on 18/08/2024. Prep involved fasting from the night before, which, let me tell you, was an ordeal in itself, especially when the aroma of Priya's butter chicken was wafting through the house.
normalised: Doctor Sharma was surprisingly chill. Listened patiently as I recounted my saga of digestive woes. He did a physical examination and then, after a thorough interrogation (about my diet, stress levels, even my family history), he suspected either gastritis or a possible ulcer. He recommended an endoscopy and a blood test to check for H. pylori. The cost? A cool rupees eight thousand for the endoscopy, and rupees one thousand five hundred for the blood work. Ouch.

He recommended an endoscopy and a blood test to check for H. pylori. The cost? A cool Rs. 8000 for the endoscopy, and Rs. 1500 for the blood work. Ouch.
normalised: The endoscopy itself wasn't as terrifying as I imagined. Sedation is a beautiful thing. Woke up feeling groggy, but at least they found the culprit: a small peptic ulcer. Doctor Sharma prescribed a course of antibiotics (Amoxicillin five hundred milligram, twice daily) and a proton pump inhibitor, Pantoprazole forty milligram, again, twice a day for two weeks. Along with a strict diet plan, of course – absolutely no spicy food, fried items, or caffeine. My beloved chai was banished!

Along with a strict diet plan, of course – absolutely no spicy food, fried items, or caffeine. My beloved chai was banished!
normalised: It's been a month since then, and I'm feeling much better, touchwood. The pain has subsided, and I'm slowly reintroducing some "normal" foods back into my diet, under Doctor Sharma’s guidance, naturally. The ulcer is healing, and I'm diligently following the medication schedule. Regular follow-up appointment on fifteenth September two thousand and twenty four to check the progress.

normalised: Moral of the story? Don't ignore those tummy rumbles! Listen to your body (and your wife). And most importantly, find a good gastroenterologist. Your gut will thank you for it. I'm just glad it wasn't anything more serious, like Crohn's or, god forbid, cancer of some sort. Now, if you'll excuse me, I’m off to find a less spicy, ulcer-friendly alternative to my beloved biryani. Wish me luck!
